question_text: How does the Hinze theory predict the turbulent kinetic energy (TKE) of particles in homogeneous isotropic stationary turbulence (HIST) under weak-drift conditions, and what are its limitations at high Stokes numbers according to the provided paper?
standard_answer: The Hinze theory predicts that for particles in HIST under weak-drift conditions (where gravitational effects are negligible), the ratio of particle turbulent kinetic energy (kp) to fluid turbulent kinetic energy (k) decreases with increasing Stokes number (StΛ) as kp/k ≈ 1/(1 + StΛ). This relationship arises from solving the particle equation of motion with linear drag and constant response time, assuming the integral time scale of fluid turbulence seen by particles (τ@p) equals the Lagrangian integral time scale (τΛL). The derivation involves Fourier decomposition of velocity fluctuations and integrating the particle velocity spectrum, showing that particle inertia filters higher-frequency turbulent fluctuations, reducing kp. However, the Hinze theory tends to underestimate kp at high Stokes numbers due to an underestimation of τ@p in this limit. Specifically, τ@p should increase to the moving-Eulerian time scale (τΛmE) per Eq. (44b) of the paper, as high-inertia particles experience longer correlation times of fluid turbulence along their paths, which is not accounted for in the Hinze assumption of τ@p = τΛL. This limitation highlights the need for corrections to accurately model particle TKE in regimes where particle inertia significantly alters the effective turbulence time scales.
